description: From Latin aggravatus, past participle of aggravare (“to add to the weight of, make worse, oppress, annoy”), from ad (“to”) + gravare (“to make heavy”), from gravis (“heavy”). See grave and compare aggrieve and aggrege.

verbs.description: aggravate (third-person singular simple present aggravates, present participle aggravating, simple past and past participle aggravated)

entries.meaning: To make (an offence) worse or more severe; to increase in offensiveness or heinousness. [from 16th c.]
examples: The defense made by the prisoner's counsel did rather aggravate than extenuate his crime.

entries.meaning: (by extension) To make worse; to exacerbate. [from 16th c.]
examples: […]  to aggravate the horrors of the scene

entries.meaning: (now rare) To give extra weight or intensity to; to exaggerate, to magnify. [from 16th c.]
(obsolete) To pile or heap (something heavy or onerous) on or upon someone. [16th–18th c.]
examples: In order to lighten the crown still further, they aggravated responsibility on ministers of state.

entries.meaning: (now chiefly colloquial) To exasperate; to provoke or irritate. [from 16th c.]
examples: Ben Bella was aggravated by having to express himself in French because the Egyptians were unable to understand his Arabic.
